p.s: Following, I am going to analyze the language and stylistic devices used in order to convey the intention of the sonnet.
The first quatrain starts with the rhetorical question, in which way beauty is able to withstand decay when even [...] brass, nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea cannot (cf. v. 1).
This impossibility is underlined by the anaphora such as by the climax [...] nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea (cf. v. 1).
In versverse four beauty is metaphorically defined as a flower.
Especially this comparison hilightshighlights the beauty's weakness.
The sadness of that is stressed by the assonance of the o in v. 4 Whose action is no stronger than a flower?.
If you read it out loud, you need to take a deep breath in because it is very monotonous and sluggish.
This sluggish breath taking process can be transferred to the attempt of trying to keep the Fair Youth's beauty alive.
Such as the assonance of the o goes on in versverse five, the helplessness does.
Therefore [...] summer's honey breath [cannot] hold out [a]gainst the wrackful siege of batt'ring days (cf. vv. 5-6).
On the one hand, time enables nature to glow but on the other hand, it steals its beauty.
That fact is underlined by the paradox in versverse seven, thus rock [...] impregnable [but at the same time] [...] not so stout.

In addition, the anaphora in versverse one [...] nor, [...] nor, [...] nor. [...] is seized in versverse eight Nor [...] to highlight that even unnatural things, for instance [...] gates of steel [...] (cf. v. 8) cannot withstand the process of aging.
However, the alliteration [...] steel so strong [...] in versverse eight highlights the material's strenghtstrenghth, the word but (cf. v. 8) encounters that immediately.
Moreover, the iambic pentameter may symbolize the tick, tack of a clock.
Keeping that in mind, whilst reading the sonnet, the reader itself, the Fair Youth, nature and everything on earth ages.
Furthermore, the lyrical voice complains about [the] [...] tearful meditation (cf. v. 9) of finding a solution to [forbid] [the Fair Youth's] spoil of beauty (cf. v. 12).
Firstly, the lyrical persona compares his addressee with the time's best jewel (cf. v. 10) which [shall hid] from time's chest lie (cf. v. 10).
That this would not make sense is underlined by the rhetorical structure of the versverse (cf. v. 10).
Further, the speaker compares his addressee with the imaginary of swift [feet] (cf. v. 11) that need a super strong hand (cf. v. 11) to be hold back.

Keeping the general amount of the Fair Youth sonnets in mind, one can asumeassume that the poet might be a little jealous (cf. v. 11) because while he is waiting for the Fair Youth to turn back to him, the Fair Youth is having fun with others.
Further, the anaphora Or what a strong hand... (cf. v. 11) and Or who his spoil... (cf. v. 12), underlined by a parallelistic sentence structure, encounters the image of ana jealous poet.
Instead, the lyrical persona explains that he is only trying to find a solution for the Fair Youth's beauty to resist decay.

The final couplet finally soluts [t]hat in black ink my love may still shine bright (cf. v. 11) which means that the Fair Youth's Beauty will everlast through the sonnetssonnet's words no matter if the young men ages or eventually dies someday.
The impossibility of that, as mentioned in the first three quatrains, is replaced by a miracle (cf. v. 13).
This [his] love (cf. v. 14), the Fair Youth, may still shine bright (cf. v. 14).
In addition, the alliteration still shine (cf. v. 14) tones that the beauty of the young man is as attention seeking as the conspicuous letter s.
To put it all in a nutshell, the language and stylistic devices of Sonnet 65 stress the intention of the poet.
Thus, the message of the sonnet's power to capture the fair youth's beauty in its words becomes evident and a significant for the fair youth sonnets.
In general, those are about the deep friendship between the fair youth and the poet, but while the poet dotsdotes on the attractive man, the man sometimes hangs around with others.
Although, the poet is aware of that he cannot stop loving the man.
Thus he writes sonnets about him to capture his love in the words of the sonnets because that is the only thing that holds a plea against natural decay and transiencetranscience
